name: Product Hero with Benefit Badge
description: Bold claim headline with comparison badge and humorous parenthetical subline

copyPlacements.description: Bold, simple claim statement. Pattern: '[Thing] is the new [thing]' or '[Benefit] in [format]' e.g. 'Fiber is the new protein.' Keep it punchy and declarative.
Comparison-based benefit claim. Pattern: 'MORE [X] THAN [Y]' e.g. 'MORE FIBER THAN 2 CUPS OF BROCCOLI'. Must be specific and comparative.
Playful parenthetical that adds personality. Pattern: '(Especially if you [relatable scenario])' - casual, self-aware humor.
Brand name on package
Product category descriptor on packaging e.g. 'Superfoods Greens Gummies'

specs.styleNotes: Clean, health-focused design with warm background and hand-held product shot. Headline is a bold declarative claim. Benefit badge uses comparison format. Humorous subline adds personality in parentheses. Keep all copy SHORT and punchy.

name: Product Hero with Social Proof
description: Minimal product hero with conversational headline and social proof badge

copyPlacements.description: Conversational headline with *emphasis* on key benefit phrase. Pattern: 'The [benefit phrase] for [audience]' e.g. 'The *no-makeup makeup* for chronically late people'
Supporting benefit statement that expands on the headline promise
Star rating and review count. Pattern: 'â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… [number] [X] STAR REVIEWS' e.g. 'â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… 29,931 5 STAR REVIEWS'

specs.styleNotes: Clean, minimal design with elegant serif headline featuring italic emphasis on key phrase. Product hero shot centered with social proof badge at bottom. Keep copy tight and conversational.

name: Product Benefits List with Hero Shot

copyPlacements.description: Main benefit-focused headline introducing the product
Numbered list of key product benefits, 6 items max

copyPlacements.style: large, bold, white text on product
copyPlacements.description: Product brand/name prominently displayed on package
Brief product description or category
Optional certification or quality badge

specs.styleNotes: Clean, minimalist design with numbered benefits list on left side and hero product shot on right. Uses neutral background with dark green product packaging. Text hierarchy emphasizes benefits over product features.

name: Split Product Benefits with Guarantee
description: Four-quadrant layout with bold headline, guarantee callout, product shot, and ingredient benefits list

copyPlacements.description: Brand name displayed small above headline
Bold benefit claim with timeframe or result. Pattern: '[RESULT] IN [TIME]' e.g. 'BETTER FOCUS IN 60 MINS'
Risk-reversal guarantee statement. Pattern: 'Or [Guarantee]' e.g. 'Or Get Your Money Back'
Ingredient benefit line. Pattern: '[Ingredient] for [benefit]' e.g. 'Lion's Mane for memory & learning'
Ingredient benefit line. Pattern: '[Ingredient] to [benefit]' e.g. 'CDP Choline to support attention'
Ingredient benefit line. Pattern: '[Ingredient] provides [benefit]' e.g. '7-8 DHF provides neuroprotection'
Product name as shown on packaging

specs.styleNotes: Four-quadrant split layout. Top-left: bold headline. Top-right: guarantee with product hero shot. Bottom-left: product packaging shot. Bottom-right: stacked ingredient benefits. Benefits must be single lines following the pattern '[Ingredient/Feature] for/to/provides [benefit keyword]'. Keep all copy tight and scannable.

name: Negative Quote-Based Product Hero
description: Sarcastic quote format using ironic statements no one would say to highlight the problem

copyPlacements.description: Sarcastic/ironic quote - something NOBODY would ever say. Pattern: 'I WANT [BAD THING]' e.g. 'I WANT MICROPLASTICS IN MY BREASTMILK'. Must be absurd and highlight the problem the product solves.
Sarcastic attribution. Pattern: 'â€” No [person] ever' e.g. 'â€” No mom ever'. NOT a real testimonial name.
Brand name
Product name/descriptor on packaging e.g. 'MICROPLASTIC BINDING PROBIOTIC'
Brief usage or dosage info

specs.styleNotes: Dark, moody product photography. The quote must be IRONIC - something absurd that nobody would say, highlighting the problem. Attribution is sarcastic ('No mom ever'), NOT a real person testimonial. This format uses humor through absurdity.

name: News Article Headline + Image
description: Fake news article layout with brand as publication, curiosity-driven headline, and testimonial body

copyPlacements.description: Brand name styled as publication/magazine name

Curiosity-driven news headline. Pattern: '[Persona] Swears by This [Benefit] Hack' e.g. 'Teacher Swears by This Morning Beauty Hack'. Must include relatable persona, use 'Swears by/Discovers/Relies on', include 'This' for curiosity gap. NO product or brand name.
Related topic links separated by pipe. Pattern: '[Topic] | "[Teaser quote]"' e.g. '2-Min Routine | "The ultimate healthy glow"'

1-2 sentence article intro with named person quote. Pattern: '[Title] [Full Name] says, "This is my little [morning/daily] secret."' e.g. '11th Grade teacher Sarah Jenkins says, "This is my little morning secret."'

specs.styleNotes: Styled like a real news article or blog post. Brand appears as publication name in masthead. Headline creates curiosity without revealing product. Body text includes a named person with their title giving a personal testimonial quote. Should feel like journalism, not advertising.

name: Native Problem-Solution
description: Q&A/forum style format with vulnerable problem question and helpful product solution - creator POV

copyPlacements.description: Category/community topic label e.g. 'GLP-1 Q&A', 'Skincare Help', 'Morning Routine'

Vulnerable first-person question from a real person struggling with a problem. MUST be casual/imperfect with ellipses, emoji optional. Pattern: 'I'm having [problem]... how do you manage?' or 'anyone else deal with [problem]??' e.g. 'I'm having trouble in the bathroom... ðŸ’© how do you manage?' Write from CREATOR POV, not brand voice.

Helpful tip pointing to product as solution. Pattern: '[Amount] of [ingredient] helps [solve problem]' e.g. '6g of fiber helps relieve bloating and constipation.' Should feel like a friend sharing a tip, not brand marketing.

specs.styleNotes: Mimics social media Q&A or forum posts. Problem question should feel vulnerable and real - someone admitting a struggle and asking for help. Solution callout feels like a helpful friend sharing what worked for them, with handwritten annotation style pointing to the product. CRITICAL: All copy must be written from creator/user POV, NOT brand voice. Casual, imperfect, human.
